set.title: Admin REST API
set.description: Admin REST API for administrative purposes

introduction.paragraph: Two REST APIs are available for Sync Gateway. We document the Public REST API in Public REST API. To interact and manage the Couchbase Server Sync Gateway, you can use the Admin APIs that are illustrated in this reference article.
The Admin REST API is a superset of the Public REST API with the following major extensions:

unordered-list.list-item: The capability to view, create, and modify users and roles.
The capability to perform management tasks such as creating and deleting databases.
The capability to perform administrative tasks without authentication. The Admin REST API operates in superuser mode—you can view and modify anything without needing a password or session cookie.

introduction.paragraph: By default, the Admin REST API runs on port 4985 (unless you change the adminInterface configuration parameter). Do not expose this port—It belongs behind your firewall. Anyone who can reach this port has free access to and control over your databases and user accounts.
introduction.note: A quick way to tell whether you are communicating with the Admin REST API is by sending a GET / request and checking whether the resulting object contains an "ADMIN": true property. HTTP requests logged to the console show the user name of the requester after the URL. If the request is made on the admin port, this is "(ADMIN)" instead.

body.note: In the URI paths shown below, any path component surrounded by curly braces, { }, is a placeholder for a name that can vary; for example, {db} refers to the name of the database.
body.paragraph: Following are resources for the Admin REST API:

row.entry: Performs operations on servers (Sync Gateway instances). Examples include getting information about a Sync Gateway instance and getting a list of all databases served by the instance.

Performs operations on databases. Examples include configuring a new database and compacting a database. Some database operations operate on all or many documents in the database, for example, getting a changes feed for all documents.
Performs operations on sessions, which permit authentication of users. Examples include creating a new session for a user and deleting a session.
Performs operations on users. Examples include creating and deleting users.
Performs operations on users. Examples include creating and deleting users.
